Award.AwardTitle: Online Chemistry: Problems, Concepts and Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Chemistry (12) The "Online Chemistry: Problems, Concepts and Contexts" project is creating a set of web-based instructional materials covering topics in introductory chemistry that are difficult to teach and learn, including stoichiometry, thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium, acid-base chemistry, and solubility. Students currently spend a substantial amount of instructional time solving quantitative problems on these topics. The online materials help to maximize the learning benefits of this time by better coupling the problem solving to chemical concepts and to the use of these concepts in modern science. The instructional modules are grounded in both the broader instructional principles of learning science and more specific results obtained from observing students solving chemistry problems. In particular, the online materials implement an instructional approach to equilibrium that initial results found to more than double student performance on difficult problems and that lays a powerful conceptual framework on which acid-base and other related topics build.

The molecular science covered in these materials is becoming an increasingly important aspect of science and engineering. By providing students with robust knowledge of chemical concepts, the modules prepare students for careers across multiple STEM disciplines. The materials are broadly disseminated through the web, conferences and publications. Because the materials are developed in a manner that allows for easy modifications, even for highly interactive components, both the original authors and the community as a whole can use the information gleaned on how students learn to iteratively improve the materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed, evaluated, and disseminated, online educational materials for use in introductory chemistry courses. The resources blend virtual labs, conceptual worked examples, tutors, and particulate-level simulations to provide coherent instruction that bridges macroscopic, molecular level and symbolic representations of chemical phenomena. The activities are set in real world contexts that highlight the utility of the knowledge and are designed to integrate easily into a broad range of classrooms and instructional settings. Topics covered include: stoichiometry, thermochemistry, kinetics, equilibrium, acid/base, solubility and redox chemistry. A central component of these online activities is a virtual laboratory simulation in which students design and interpret their own experiments. This project greatly expanded the number of activities available for the virtual laboratory, including tutorials on difficult aspects of chemistry that couple virtual laboratory experiments to online tutors and authentic real-world contexts. All activities were tested in classrooms and revised based on the results of these tests. The materials are freely available at www.chemcollective.org. In the last year of the project, chemcollective.org had 715,000 unique visitors, 450,000 virtual lab activities were run online and 30,000 visitors ran the Mixed Reception murder mystery activity. The project also published 8 papers, ran 6 teacher workshops, presented 11 talks at education conferences, and had booths in the exhibit hall at 6 teacher conferences. Classroom support is also provided online.
